newsitem.title: UK: TENNIS-NOVOTNA AND SANCHEZ VICARIO TO MEET IN DELAYED FINAL.
newsitem.headline: TENNIS-NOVOTNA AND SANCHEZ VICARIO TO MEET IN DELAYED FINAL.

text.p: Arantxa Sanchez Vicario battled through the quarter-finals and semifinals of the Eastbourne women's grasscourt tournament on Saturday and then decided she needed a night's rest before the final against Jana Novotna.
With a backlog of matches after two days of rain, organisers had hoped to cram in the final three rounds of the tournament on Saturday.

But they left the decision on the timing of the final to Sanchez Vicario who, exhausted after beating Irina Spirlea in the quarter-finals and hard-hitter Brenda Schultz-McCarthy in Saturday's second semifinal, asked not to be sent straight back on court. Novotna agreed.
The final will be played at 1100 local (1000 GMT) on Sunday, weather permitting.
Novotna, who beat Natasha Zvereva 6-7 6-0 7-5 in the earlier semifinal, had at least had an hour's rest while Sanchez Vicario beat Schultz-McCarthy 7-5 6-1.
Schultz-McCarthy, the eighth seed, had beaten defending champion Monica Seles 7-5 7-5 earlier on Saturday in a quarter-final which began on Thursday and was then postponed because of the rain.
Second seed Novotna struggled all day with windy conditions and her own inability to kill off her opponents when presented with golden opportunities.
Her first engagement on Saturday was to resume her quarter- final against Japan's Ai Sugiyama which was interrupted by rain on Friday with the Czech 6-2 6-5 up and the score at 15-15.

Three more points would have clinched victory for Novotna but she took the hard route, failing to convert a matchpoint and then hitting a double fault to surrender a break which took the second set to the tiebreak.
A double fault followed on another matchpoint and Sugiyama won the tiebreak 8-6.
The third set saw Novotna playing perfect serve-and-volley tennis one minute and hitting ghastly errors the next before a break of serve in the 10th game finally gave her victory.

But the win did little for her self-belief and she was even more erratic against Belarussian Zvereva in the semifinals, surrendering a 5-3 lead in the opening set and, after a one-hour rain break, being broken three times as she served for the set.

Zvereva won a first-set tiebreak 9-7, went down to love in a second set which saw one game go 11 times to deuce before Novotna converted her eighth breakpoint and saved four more matchpoints in the third set before Novotna won 7-5.

Zvereva had beaten Frenchwoman Nathalie Tauziat 6-4 5-7 6-4 in the quarter-finals. Tauziat later withdrew from a doubles match with a pulled thigh muscle and was expected to consult doctors at Wimbledon on Sunday.

Top seed Seles, whose quarter-final had been suspended on Thursday at 7-5 2-2 to Schultz-McCarthy, had trouble with her serve and admitted she still had some work to do to prepare for Wimbledon next week.

"There are little things that I need to adjust for me to improve," said the American who admitted she was sorely missing her father and coach Karolj who is seriously ill with cancer in the United States.
